biogHists.text:
George E. Probst (1917-1986) held many positions in both broadcasting and education from 1944 to 1983: Executive Director, Office of Radio and Television, University of Chicago (1944-1954); Founder, director and Producer, University of Chicago Roundtable (NBC) (1944-1954); Chairman, committee that presented before the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) the case for assigning television channels for education (1949-1950): Chairman, finance committee, Joint Committee on Educational Television (JCET) (1950-1952); Chairman, Committee of all educational institutions, Chicago Metropolitan Area Educational Television (1951-1953; Chairman, Adult Education Committee administering Fund for Adult Education grant for production of radio series The Jefferson Heritage (co-author), Ways of Mankind, People Under Communism, Voice of Europe (1951-1953); Director, radio and television programming, WGBH (Boston, MA) (1954); Co-founder, President, Broadcast Foundation of America (1955-1983); Producer, director, writer, Democracy in America, a series based on Alexis de Tocqueville's observations of American life and politics (1958); Director, National Educational Television and Radio Center (1960-1966); Executive Director, National Commission for Cooperative Education (1966-1976); Consultant, U.S. Office of Education (1968-1976).

From the guide to the George E. Probst Papers, 1970, 2007, 1970, (National Public Broadcasting Archives)

relations.content: Howe, M. A. De Wolfe (Mark Antony De Wolfe), 1864-1960
National Conference on Citizens Rights in Broadcasting (1970 : New York)

resource.title: Mark Anthony De Wolfe Howe additional papers, 1880-1959
resource.abstract: Primarily professional correspondence of biographer and editor M. A. De Wolfe Howe.
resource.displayEntry: Howe, M. A. De Wolfe (Mark Antony De Wolfe), 1864-1960. Additional papers, 1880-1959

originationNames.name: Howe, M. A. De Wolfe (Mark Antony De Wolfe),                    1864-1960.

resource.title: Paul A. Freund papers
resource.abstract: The Papers of Paul Freund consist of materials related to his work as government lawyer, author, teacher, authority on Constitutional Law, and as a member of numerous organizations, such as the American Association of Arts and Sciences.
resource.displayEntry: Freund, Paul A. Paul A. Freund papers. 1918-1993.

nameEntries.original: Harvard Law School Library, Harvard University.

resource.title: Lon L. Fuller papers
resource.abstract: Collection includes  correspondence (letters received and carbons of letters  sent), "fan" mail, telegrams, memoranda, minutes of  meetings, reports, research notes, lecture notes,  examination papers, bibliographies, outlines, drafts,  manuscripts of published and unpublished writings and  speeches, news clippings, other printed items,  "preliminary" editions of books, and association copies of  books.
resource.displayEntry: Fuller, Lon L. Lon L. Fuller papers. 1926-1977.

nameEntries.original: Harvard Law School Library, Harvard University.

resource.title: William Ernest Hocking papers 1860-1979
resource.abstract: Correspondence of Harvard philosopher William Ernest Hocking, his wife, Agnes Hocking, the Hocking family, and others.
resource.displayEntry: Hocking, William Ernest, 1873-1966. William Ernest Hocking Papers, 1860-1979

Probst  (1917-1986) held many positions in both broadcasting and education from 1944 to 1983: Executive Director, Office of Radio and Television, University of Chicago (1944-1954); Founder, director and Producer, <title>University of Chicago Roundtable</title> (NBC) (1944-1954); Chairman, committee that presented before the <extref>Federal Communications Commission (FCC)</extref> the case for assigning television channels for education (1949-1950): Chairman, finance committee, <extref>Joint Committee on Educational Television (JCET)</extref> (1950-1952); Chairman, Committee of all educational institutions, Chicago Metropolitan Area Educational Television (1951-1953; Chairman, Adult Education Committee administering Fund for Adult Education grant for production of radio series <title>The Jefferson Heritage</title> (co-author), <title>Ways of Mankind</title>, <title>People Under Communism</title>, <title>Voice of Europe</title>(1951-1953); Director, radio and television programming, <extref>WGBH (Boston, MA)</extref> (1954); Co-founder, President, Broadcast Foundation of America (1955-1983); Producer, director, writer,<title>Democracy in America</title>, a series based on Alexis de Tocqueville's observations of American life and politics (1958); Director, <extref>National Educational Television and Radio Center</extref> (1960-1966); Executive Director, National Commission for Cooperative Education (1966-1976); Consultant, U.S. Office of Education (1968-1976). The collection documents Probst's participation in National Conference on Citizens Rights in Broadcasting, October 1970 as well as the public television programms: <title>Tocqueville's America</title> and <title>The University of Chicago Roundtable</title>.</abstract>
